importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when President Trump filed an emergency appeal to the Supreme Court seeking permission to deploy the National Guard in Chicago, marking a pivotal moment in the legal battle over presidential power and military deployment.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe when the Supreme Court requested responses from state and local officials by Monday evening, indicating an accelerated judicial process in response to the emergency appeal.

keyTakeAways: President Donald Trump filed an emergency appeal to the Supreme Court asking for authorization to deploy the National Guard in Chicago, citing an alleged pre-planned ambush involving multiple assailants threatening federal personnel and property.
Lower federal courts, including the 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, had previously blocked the deployment, arguing that Trump overstated the emergency and improperly invoked national guard use.

The Trump administration claims that courts are improperly interfering with the president's commander-in-chief authority, referencing the 1827 Supreme Court case Martin v. Mott, which held that only the president can determine whether a national emergency exists.

In contrast, states challenging the deployment have referenced the 1932 case Sterling v. Constantin, where the Supreme Court allowed judicial review of a governor's decision to deploy the National Guard, arguing that such decisions fall outside a range of honest judgment.

The appeal uses strong language describing the situation in Chicago as a 'harrowing pre-planned ambush,' contrasting sharply with Judge April Perry’s earlier description of protests as non-violent expressions of dissent.
The Supreme Court, which has generally sided with Trump in previous emergency deployments, is now facing a pivotal test of presidential power versus judicial oversight in national security matters.

summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump has filed an emergency appeal to the Supreme Court requesting authorization to deploy the National Guard in Chicago, asserting that federal personnel face a violent, pre-planned ambush and that the president’s authority to declare a national emergency is not subject to judicial review. This move follows a prior blocking order by the 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, which found Trump’s emergency claim excessive. The administration cites the 1827 Supreme Court case Martin v. Mott to justify its position that only the president can determine the existence of a national emergency. However, states and judicial officials challenge this, pointing to the 1932 case Sterling v. Constantin, which allows courts to review executive decisions when they fall outside a 'range of honest judgment.' The case highlights a significant constitutional conflict between presidential power and judicial oversight in national security matters, with the Supreme Court requesting a rapid response from state and local officials.
title: Trump asks Supreme Court to OK National Guard deployment in Chicago
